raw_text:
Video phones act as dating tools
 
 Technologies, from e-mail, to net chatrooms, instant messaging and mobiles, have proved to be a big pull with those looking for love.
 
 The lure once was that you could hide behind the technology, but now video phones are in on the act to add vision. Hundreds have submitted a mobile video profile to win a place at the world's first video mobile dating event. The top 100 meet their match on 30 November at London's Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA). The event, organised by the 3G network, 3, could catch on as the trend for unusual dating events, like speed dating, continues. "It's the beginning of the end of the blind date as we know it," said Graeme Oxby, 3's marketing director. The response has been so promising that 3 says it is planning to launch a proper commercial dating service soon. Hundreds of hopefuls submitted their profiles, and special booths were set up in a major London department store for two weeks where expert tips were given on how to visually improve their chances. The 100 most popular contestants voted by the public will gather at the ICA in separate rooms and "meet" by phone.
 
 Dating services and other more adult match-making services are proving to be a strong stream of revenue worth millions for mobile companies. Whether it does actually provide an interesting match for video phone technologies remains to be seen. Flic Everett, journalist and dating expert for Company magazine and the Daily Express, thinks technology has been liberating for some nervous soul-mate seekers. There are currently about 1.3 million video phones in use in the UK and three times more single people in Britain than there were 30 years ago, With more people buying video mobiles, 3G dating could be the basis for a successful and safe way to meet people.
 
 "One of the problems with video phones is people don't really know what to video. It is a weird technology. We have not quite worked out what it is for. This gives it a focus and a useful one," she told BBC News. "I would never have thought online dating would take off the way it did," she said. "Lots of people find it easier to be honest writing e-mail or text than face-to-face. Lots people are quite shy and they feel vulnerable." "When you are writing, it comes directly onto the page so they tend to be more honest." But the barrier that comes with SMS chat and online match-making is that the person behind the profile may not be who they really are. Scare stories have put people off as a result, according to Ms Everett. Many physical clues, body language, odd twitches, are obviously missing with SMS and online dating services. Still images do not necessarily provide all those necessary cues. "It could really take off because you do get the whole package. With a static e-mail picture, you don't know who the person is behind it is." So checking out a potential date by video phone also gives singletons a different kind of barrier, an extra layer of protection; a case of WLTS before WLTM. "If you are trapped in real-life blind date context, you can't get away and you feel embarrassed. "With a video meeting, you really have the barrier of the phone so if you don't like them you don't have to suffer the embarrassment."
 
 There is a more serious side to this new use of technology though. With money being made through more adult-themes content and services which let people meet and chat, the revenue streams for mobile carriers will grow with 3G, thinks Paolo Pescatore mobile industry specialist for analysts IDC. "Wireless is a medium that is being exploited with a number of features and services. One is chatting and the dating element is key there," he said. "The foundation has been set by SMS and companies are using media like MMS and video to grow the market further." But carriers need to be wary and ensure that if they do launch such 3G dating services, they ensure mechanism are in place to monitor and be aware who is registers and accesses these services on regular basis, he cautioned. In July, Vodafone introduced a content control system to protect children from such adult content. The move was as a result of a code of practice agreed by the UK's six largest mobile phone operators in January. The system means Vodafone users need to prove they are over 18 before firewalls are lifted on explicit websites or chat rooms dealing with adult themes. The impetus was the growing number of people with handsets that could access the net, and the growth of 3G technologies.
llama3.2:1b:
Video phones act as dating tools due to their popularity for connecting individuals looking for love. Many have submitted video profiles to win a place at a mobile video dating event, which will take place on November 30th at the London Institute of Contemporary Arts. The event, organised by the 3G network, is expected to catch on as people seek unusual and innovative ways to meet potential partners.

The top 100 contestants will be selected through public voting, with tips provided by expert advice given in a major department store for two weeks. The event aims to revolutionize the blind date, offering a more personal connection between individuals. However, experts note that video phones may not provide a convincing match due to issues surrounding anonymity and verification.

Mobile companies are experiencing significant revenue growth through dating services and adult-themed content, which could be linked to 3G's potential for mobile video dating. Experts warn carriers about the need to establish measures in place to monitor and regulate these services to ensure safety and protection from explicit content.
llama3.2:3b: Video phones being used for dating due to rise in mobile use, hundreds submitted profiles for first video mobile dating event in London's ICA, technology seen as liberating for nervous match-makers, experts think video calls provide whole package including physical cues missing from static images and online services, carriers must ensure mechanisms are in place to monitor users, revenue streams expected to grow with adult-themed content and services.

This "3G dating" event will test this new format's success as it aims to offer a more personal approach than traditional methods. The potential benefits include greater honesty in self-presentation and reduced anxiety due to the ability to decline dates without embarrassment.

The technology has been praised as more honest than online dating services due to the physical contact offered by video calls. However, concerns remain about whether it will be a safe or reliable way for people to find love over video phones.

The event is part of the 3G network's plan to launch a commercial dating service based on video phone technology, expected to provide an interesting match for singles. Video phones have advantages over traditional methods like SMS and online matches, offering more reliable visual information about potential partners. However, there are privacy concerns and safeguards need to be implemented to protect users from adult content misuse.

However, it also notes some potential drawbacks, such as the lack of regulation and the risk of scams or exploitation. The article suggests that carriers may need to take steps to ensure that their 3G dating services are safe and responsible, and that they comply with existing regulations and guidelines.

Hundreds submitted profiles at a London event called ICA 2018, attracting top performers. Single people in the UK are more than triple what they were twenty years ago due to growing mobile usage and 3G adoption. The tech is effective for e-mails and text but lacks face-to-face protection. This new form of datings is seen as a possible step towards more adult-themed content and services for mobile carriers, with the potential revenues for these carriers growing further through 3G. VoDAfonE, one of the UK's largest mobile phone operators, has recently introduced a content control system to protect children from such adult content. The impetus behind this was the Code of Practice agreed by UK's six largest mobile phone operators in January, which required users to prove they are over 18 before opening firewalls on explicit websites or chat rooms dealing with adult theme.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Video dating is a trend in the world of online communication, where people can meet others through various forms of video communication such as mobile video profiles, instant messaging or even video chatting rooms. These platforms allow users to connect with people from all around the world, and offer an exciting new way to find love and build relationships. 

On November 30th, London's Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) hosted a video mobile dating event, aimed at providing participants with the chance to meet and interact with others before making their final decision on who they would like to date. Over 1,000 people participated in this unique event, with many expressing their excitement for the new technology that is allowing users to connect more easily than ever before.

The main aim of these video dating events is to introduce participants to a diverse range of potential romantic partners and create a platform for them to express themselves, find common interests, and discuss any concerns they may have in order to make their decision on who they want to date. This interactive approach not only increases the chances of finding love among the participants, but also provides users with an opportunity to learn more about each other before committing to a long-term relationship.

Dating services are proving to be popular, with many people looking for unique experiences and ways to meet new people. Video dating is a growing trend, and it remains to be seen whether it will ultimately replace traditional forms of dating or provide an alternative way of meeting romantic partners. However, the technology behind video dating provides exciting possibilities for users who enjoy a variety of communication methods.

However, there are concerns about the safety and authenticity of people's profiles on online dating sites. This has led some carriers to implement age verification systems to protect children from accessing adult content.

However, carriers need to be wary and ensure mechanism are in place to monitor and be aware who is registers and accesses these services on regular basis.

While online dating has helped shy individuals express themselves more honestly, video phones provide additional cues like body language. However, concerns remain about the potential misuse of such technology, particularly in adult-themed content. granite3.1-dense:2b:
Video phones are emerging as a novel tool for online dating, capitalizing on the trend of unconventional dating events like speed dating. The world's first video mobile dating event, organized by the 3G network, will take place at London's ICA on November 30th, where 100 participants selected from hundreds who submitted mobile video profiles will "meet" via phone. This innovation aims to address the limitations of text-based communication in online dating, offering visual cues that can help users better gauge compatibility.

The response to this concept has been enthusiastic, with 3G planning a commercial dating service based on its success. Mobile companies view video dating as a promising revenue source, generating millions from adult matchmaking services. Flic Everett, a journalist and dating expert, believes that video phones could liberate nervous daters by providing a structured focus for communication.

However, potential concerns exist regarding privacy and authenticity, as some users may misrepresent themselves in text-based interactions due to the anonymity it offers. Video phone dating is expected to offer additional protection, allowing singles to assess potential partners without feeling trapped in traditional blind dates.

The mobile industry specialist Paolo Pescatore warns that carriers must implement robust monitoring systems to prevent unauthorized access to adult content by minors. In July, Vodafone introduced a content control system requiring users over 18 to access explicit material, following a code of practice agreed upon by the UK's six largest mobile operators in January. This move reflects growing concerns about children accessing adult-themed content via 3G technologies.
